job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Good health insurance, 12 sick days 4 weeks vacation and 3 personal.
cons: Supervisors make you feel disposable. They tells you to put up with the ridiculous workload because "You should be happy you still have a job." Nurses complain daily about the workload but managers and supervisors don't care because they don't have to do it themselves. Not sure who in HR or MJHS we can turn to or if they can even do anything about it. Management is all about productivity and focuses on quantity instead of quality. Pre-COVID we were asked to see 12 patients a week for UAS, now we are asked to see about 30 and they hound us when we cannot meet productivity, when it is physically impossible. Management should understand that anything we are asked to do as a part of our job should count towards productivity including mandatory HR trainings.

review_title: It's been a good ride so far..
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
I haven't worked at MJHS for long, but so far I have no regrets. Management has a GREAT open door policy from high-level to middle-management. I find myself going to them when I need assistance and they seem to encourage it! The rest of the staff is very easy to get along with too. Management usually has the staff work together, so things get done efficiently without too much falling on one person. I've been working here a little under a year now and I've seen a LOT of people get promoted in various departments and then seen people get hired to replace those promoted. So it seems like the company is doing very well and there's a lot of room for advancement, which excites me for the future.

HR gives cash incentives if you recommend nurses and they get hired.
They recently had a company wide walking challenge. You form teams, you're given pedometers and the winning team won a trip for each member, plus 1, to Spain! They company covers it! I've been told they do this every year with a different location, so I'm excited for the next one.
They have REALLY good benefits and they don't take much out of my check so that's always a plus! On top of that everyone gets their birthday off PAID!  It's been a good ride so far, looking forward to see what's next!
cons: No real serious cons, they can do a little more to build a better work-life balance. Maybe more casual Friday's! I work in the corporate office in Brooklyn and there's not much to eat around here. I would personally love it if they offered some more variety in the cafeteria!

job_title: Care Management Coordinator in Brooklyn, NY

cons: Can’t find any this is my first week

job_title: CMC in Brooklyn, NY

job_title: Assessment Nurse in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
In these uncertain times the problems here are not specific to MJHS. Time will tell, but they have no laid off any of their nurses to date, which speaks well to their values. 

The caseload itself is very manageable once you get the hang of things. Like any job, it will take you 6 months to a year to 'master' the job. My supervisor is extremely respectful, kind, and organized. Not all supervisors are created equal, but it appears most are of the same quality. 

MJS has a 'e-mail culture'. You will typically get 50-70 emails per day. It was overwhelming for me initially but now I keep my mailbox clean throughout the day. I prefer this much more than a supervisor who calls you about every matter. 

If layoffs do happen, I would prefer to be re-assigned within MJHS. I love the culture here and the commitment to excellence.
cons:
When we were in the field, we could have used more assistance with RFS appointments. You can't schedule to far in advance because an RFS will blow up your schedule. There needs to be a better scheduling system if and when nurses have to return to the field. 

Maximus and mediciad is a complete mess right now. You can only hope we have jobs in one year.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great organization. Caring for the sick.
cons: No cons. Caring for the sick, a noble cause.

job_title: Project Leader in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great benefits, flexibility with schedule, good leaders in certain depts.
cons: Slow to adapt to times, especially with remote work.

job_title: Office Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great benefits and friendly work environment
cons: There are really not any I can think of.

job_title: Office Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Interactive and supportive managers and supervisors.
Compensates well based from experience and performance. 
Good communication between field staff and supervisors.
cons: This WAS a great company to work for. Unfortunately, they had to let go of most of the people who are great workers, who had a long time relationship with the company, and people who showed great dedication to their work. Most of them just received e-mails early in the morning telling them to come in for an “unexpected mandatory meeting” having no idea on what’s completely going on. This company downsized THREE times since 2018 affecting all departments except of course the “power personnels”. Every time they let go of employees, they always said “hopefully this move would stabilize the company” and “we are hemorrhaging money”. This company strives because of the people that was let go. Most of the people that was left in the field are too spread out making your travel distance to more than 45 minutes at least from one patient to another. This is now a very depressing place to work in. Office morale is down and the place just turned dim because you’ll never know when your going to get the boot.

review_title: Terrible inadequate management and hostile office staff
job_title: Hospice Care Planner in New York, NY
pros:
I get a pay check every two weeks and have met amazing people at different hospitals I am assigned (not MJHS employees)
three week paid orientation with an amazing educator
cons:
Claim to give a $10,000 sign on bonus when they hire you, neglecting to inform the new hire that it is vested over three years. 
They gave a great orientation but did not carve out ONE day to focus on the job that I was hired for. 
Management does not know what they are doing and lack in their ability to communicate in an effective and positive way. 
If you work in the office get prepared to have some serious mean girl interactions. The manager of the staff is too fearful of firing anyone so the aggressive angry environment continues. 
The only time a field  employee hears from their manager is when they call to ask why you are not bringing in business. But god forbid they call to say "great job"
the worker then actually makes their numbers with no response or feedback.
the worker has patients to admit (as demanded by management) but then there are no admission nurses to admit them.

review_title: This is by far the most dysfunctional company known to man.
job_title: Hospice RN Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: You do not have to be smart to work as a patient care RN.  If you have not worked in an acute care setting in a long time and are unfamiliar with basic human anatomy and physiology, you would do well here.
cons:
If your IQ is above 75, you’ll be ridiculed by management and administration for advocating for patients.  Administrators have not touched a patient in decades. It’s obvious since they are not current with modern medications, technology, and disease process.  If you are home on hospice as a patient and are diagnosed with lung cancer and have four months to live and are currently stable, nursing administration and management will ensure that RNs will tell the family not to call 911 for emergent rectal bleeding or abdominal pain.  They’ll instruct the patient and family to “administer morphine and not to call 911 because you will be kicked off the hospice service”.  

One of the directors of nursing is a social worker.  Another has a doctorate with scant hospital and patient care experience.  

The pay is awful and there is never time and a half for nurses or social workers.  Clerical associates get time and a half though. 

Trust me. Don’t work here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Friendly coworkers 
Free coffee 
Bathroom privileges 
Great benefits 
Good orientation 
Warm welcome on your first day 
Very friendly coworkers 
I’m reaching to meet the 20 word minimum
cons:
Unfortunately, they’re a ton. 
I’m an RN. No job we ever have is deemed “easy”. We are used to working hard, bending over backwards and supporting one another, 
This is not a company that provides a healthy environment for nurses to thrive. I’m speaking on CM area only. We were overworked, stressed out, disheartened. The membership for the insurance is much lower than other insurance companies but the levels of stress are way higher, purely due to disorganization. workflows are constantly changing. If membership increased, the company would fall in on itself. The amount of redundant work is appalling.  Nurses work very late to stay afloat. It’s unacceptable and not healthy. 
Beware. The benefits are excellent and incomparable, but you won’t have time to use them. I hate being negative but this is what I lived through.

job_title: Managed Care Coordinator in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Health benefits, nearby the train station
cons: Supervisors get promoted based on who they know personally. Highly unknowledgeable supervisors who rely heavily on overworking the coordinating staff who are not compensated fairly in terms of pay. Micromanagement. Lack of respect. Being overlooked by inexperienced supervisors (who lack knowledge) like being monitored by a watch dog. If you hire someone, trust that they can get the job done. High turnover. Will often ask someone who is "new" to train someone who is "new". Where is the logic in this? All in all, great if you need work experience. No room for advancement unless you know them personally. Listen to your employees more. Give people some respect. Be a leader, not a micromanager. "Respect is earned, Honesty is appreciated. Trust is gained. Loyalty is returned."

review_title: A great place that really cares about employees
job_title: Client Manager in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great contest/challenges through wellness program, Positive Steps. My team won a trip to Madrid and Barcelona in the 2015 walking challenge! When you also consider the professional opportunities and great co-workers, it's no surprise that so many people stay working here for so long. After all, we all like to feel valued and important, don't we?
cons: We all have bad days from time to time, but that doesn't mean it's the employer's fault.

job_title: RN COC in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Meet interesting patients in their homes
cons: Absolutely the worst company I have ever worked for! They force you to take on a workload as if you're a robot. They promise you a 35 hour work week on the job offer but it ends up being about 60 hours a week.  You are expected to work at home and not get paid if you fall behind on paperwork from a chaotic, overworked week. The management speaks in programmed response to multiple situations regarding productivity.   If u want to be worked like a mule, strap on one of their heavy backpacks and become an unappreciated robot.  Very little job satisfaction and very little praise for your hard work from upper management.  Worst job, worst management ever in my professional career.  I would not recommend this job to anyone!

job_title: Medical Social Worker in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Competitive Salary.  Respectful staff. Quickly address/mediate disputes.
cons: Upper management administers  periodic (every two years or so) massive, unsubstantiated lay offs. Good productive workers, in good standing, laid off. For those who have been employed longer, it creates an uncertain work environment.

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Attractive benefits such as the pension plan, paid time off, tuition reimbursement; you will get adequate training before going on your own.
cons: Despite generous tuition assistant program, you won't have time to go to school because there is NO work life balance. Your case load just keeps getting heavier and heavier because there is such a high staff turnover. Work done when documented requires needless duplication...usually to facilitate ease of information access for middle management...resulting in wasted time which contributes to fatigue and burn-out.

review_title: Great benefits and salary , but management is poor.

review_title: It was the worst. I hated waking up in the morning knowing that I had to work there.

review_title: Good company with lots of room for growth.
